infobox.date: 23 May 1706<ref>All dates in the article are in the Gregorian calendar (unless otherwise stated). The Julian calendar as used in England in 1706 differed by eleven days. See the article [[Old Style and New Style dates]] for a more detailed explanation of the dating issues and conventions.</ref>

infobox.place: [[Blindheim]] (Engl.: Blenheim),<ref>The village of Blindheim (''Blenheim'' in English) lies on the Danube River, {{convert|10|mi|km|abbr=off}} southwest of Donauwörth in Bavaria, southern Germany.</ref> near [[Höchstädt an der Donau|Höchstädt]], [[Bavaria]],<ref>In 1704, Blindheim was in the principality of Palatinate-Neuburg (Pfalz-Neuburg), which was absorbed into Bavaria in 1808.</ref> Germany

infobox.strength2:
Modern estimates range from 12,000 (outnumbering the English 4:3){{sfn|Curry|2006|p=192}} to 36,000 (outnumbering the English 6:1;{{sfn|Barker|2005|p=320}} see [[Battle of Agincourt#Numbers at Agincourt|Numbers at Agincourt]].)
About 10,000 knights and men-at-arms (of which about 1,200 were mounted), unknown thousands of other infantry, crossbowmen and archers.
infobox.result: <!-- not Decisive per consensus and sources; see talk -->English victory
infobox.caption: The Battle of Agincourt, 15th-century miniature, [[Enguerrand de Monstrelet]]
infobox.strength1:
Modern estimates range from 6,000{{sfn|Barker|2005|p=227}} to 9,000{{sfn|Curry|2006|p=192}}
(see [[Battle of Agincourt#Numbers at Agincourt|Numbers at Agincourt]].) About {{frac|5|6}} longbowmen, {{frac|1|6}} dismounted knights and men-at-arms in heavy armour.
infobox.casualties2: 7,000–10,000 (mostly killed) and about 1,500 noble prisoners (executed)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://geocities.com/beckster05/Agincourt/AgAftermath.html |title=Agincourt aftermath |accessdate=2010-10-11 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091027132428/http://geocities.com/beckster05/Agincourt/AgAftermath.html |archivedate=27 October 2009 |df=dmy }}</ref>{{unreliable source|date=October 2017}}{{Verification failed|date=October 2017}}

* Ascension of [[House of Tudor|Tudor dynasty]]

infobox.date:
23 August 1942 – 2 February 1943
({{Age in years, months, weeks and days|month1=08|day1=23|year1=1942|month2=02|day2=02|year2=1943}})
infobox.result:
Decisive<ref name="Bellamy2007">{{harvnb|Bellamy|2007|pp=}}</ref> [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] victory
* Destruction of the German [[6th Army (Wehrmacht)|6th Army]]
* Expulsion of the Germans from the Caucasus, reversing their gains from the 1942 Summer Campaign
infobox.units2:
{{Unbulleted list
|{{Flagicon|Soviet Union|1923}} [[Stalingrad Front]]{{Unordered list
| {{Flagicon|Soviet Union|1923}} [[28th Army (Soviet Union)|28th Army]]
| {{Flagicon|Soviet Union|1923}} [[51st Army (Soviet Union)|51st Army]]
| {{Flagicon|Soviet Union|1923}} [[List of Soviet armies|57th Army]]
| {{Flagicon|Soviet Union|1923}} [[62nd Army (Soviet Union)|62nd Army]]
| {{Flagicon|Soviet Union|1923}} [[64th Army (Soviet Union)|64th Army]]}}
|{{Flagicon|Soviet Union|1923}} [[Don Front]]<ref group="Note">The Soviet front's composition and names changed several times in the battle. The battle started with the South Western Front. It was later renamed Stalingrad Front, then had the Don Front split off from it.</ref>
|{{Flagicon|Soviet Union|1923}} [[Southwestern Front (Soviet Union)|South West Front]]<ref group="Note">The Front was reformed from reserve armies on 22 October 1942.</ref>}}

infobox.strength2:
195,000 men{{harvnb|Playfair||p=30}}
1,029 tanks{{efn|1,029 tanks were operational at the start of the battle: 170 M3 Grant and 252 M4 Sherman medium tanks, 216 Crusader II and 78 Crusader III Cruiser tanks, 119 M3 Stuart (Honey) light tanks and 194 Valentine [[Infantry tank]]s. There were 200 replacement tanks and over 1,000 tanks were in various stages of repair, overhaul or being modified at workshops.{{harvnb|Playfair||p=9}}}}
435 armoured cars
730{{efn|There was a front line strength of 420 fighters, of which only 50 were [[Supermarine Spitfire]] and nearly half were [[Hawker Hurricane]]s.{{harvnb|Barr||p=304}}}} – 750 aircraft (530 serviceable){{efn|This figure excludes 54 transport aircraft.}}
892 – 908 artillery pieces
1,451 anti-tank guns{{efn|554 were [[Ordnance QF 2 pounder|2 pounder]] anti-tank guns and 849 [[Ordnance QF 6 pounder|6 pounder]]s.{{harvnb|Playfair||p=10}}}}

116,000 men{{harvnb|Buffetaut||p=95}}{{efn|In Playfair the estimate for this figure is 104,000 comprising 54,000 Italians and 50,000 Germans including the 19th [[Flak]] Division and the Ramcke Parachute Brigade, both ''Luftwaffe'' units. There were approximately 77,000 Italians in North Africa who did not come under the ''Panzerarmee''.}}
547 tanks{{efn|249 German tanks and 298 Italian tanks: 31 [[Panzer II]], 85 [[Panzer III]] (short 50mm main gun), 88 Panzer III (long 50mm main gun), 8 [[Panzer IV]] (short 75mm main gun), 30 Panzer IV (long 75mm main gun), 7 command tanks, 278 [[Fiat M13/40]] variants and 20 Italian light tanks; another 23 German tanks under repair, have been excluded.{{harvnb|Playfair||pp=9–11}}}}
192 armoured cars
770 – 900 aircraft (480 serviceable){{efn|275 German (150 serviceable) including 80 dive bombers) and 400 Italian (200 serviceable) aircraft. There was a further 225 (130 serviceable) German bombers in Italy and Greece. There were 300 German and Italian transport aircraft not included in the total.{{harvnb|Playfair||p=3}}}}
552 artillery pieces
496 anti-tank guns{{efn|68 7.65 cm (Source possibly means the [[7.62 cm PaK 36(r)]]) anti-tank guns, 290 [[5 cm PaK 38|50mm Pak 38]] anti-tank guns, [[88 mm gun|88mm flak guns]].}} – 1,063{{harvnb|Barr||p=276}}
